Exaggerate: The claim suggests that voter identification laws make it "complicated and expensive" to get an ID, essentially instituting a modern-day poll tax. This may be an exaggeration as the claim does not provide sufficient evidence to support this assertion.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that voter identification laws are complicated and expensive without providing enough support or evidence to back up this assumption.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide enough evidence or data to support the assertion that voter identification laws make it complicated and expensive to get an ID.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations or perspectives regarding the purpose and impact of voter identification laws. It presents one side of the argument without acknowledging opposing viewpoints.
